title: Royal Opera House facing ticket row after majority of seats for must-see show sell out day before official sale
text:
The Royal Opera House has found itself in the midst of a ticket row after the majority of seats for next year's must-see show have sold out the day before they go on general sale.

For six nights in March 2020, the British home of opera is set to host more than 13,000 people for Beethoven's Fidelio starring "the world's greatest tenor" Jonas Kaufmann.

But only “hundreds” of tickets have been kept back for general sale starting on Thursday after the large majority have been sold to members, known as Friends of Covent Garden, leaving little chance for ordinary opera lovers to experience the “hotly anticipated” performance.

Membership packages for the Opera House range from £105 to £2,500 a year, allowing Friends of Covent Garden to access advanced tickets for the Fidelio - costing up to £275 each - seven weeks before the public from September 3.

The move has attracted criticism from those within the industry as the Royal Opera House is heavily subsidised by taxpayers through Arts Council England, receiving more than £25 million in public funding per year.
